[[University of Rochester]] |school_tradition = |main_interests = |notable_ideas = |influences = }} '''Partha Chatterjee''' ({{lang-bn|পার্থ চট্টোপাধ্যায়}}; born 5 November 1947) is an Indian political scientist and anthropologist.{{cite web|title=Faculty page: Partha Chatterjee|url=http://www.columbia.edu/cu/mesaas/faculty/directory/chatterjee.html|website=Middle Eastern, South Asian, and African Studies|publisher=www.columbia.edu|accessdate=5 June 2017|language=en}} He was the director of the [[Centre for Studies in Social Sciences, Calcutta]] from 1997 to 2007 and continues as an honorary professor of political science. He is also a professor of anthropology and [[MESAAS|South Asian studies]] at [[Columbia University]] and a member of the [[Subaltern Studies Collective]]. Chatterjee received the [[Fukuoka Asian Culture Prize]] in 2009{{cite web|url=http://www.asianmonth.com/prize/english/winner/index.html|title=Past Laureates: Fukuoka Prize|publisher=[[Fukuoka]]|accessdate=19 August 2011}} ==Education== He completed a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] (1967) and an [[Master of Arts|M.A]] (1970) in political science from [[Presidency College, Calcutta]] and [[Calcutta University]] respectively. He completed his Ph.D. (1972) in international relations from the [[University of Rochester]].{{cite web|last1=Wheeler|first1=William|title=Presidential Lectures: Partha Chatterjee|url=https://prelectur.stanford.edu/lecturers/chatterjee/|website=prelectur.stanford.edu|accessdate=5 June 2017|ref=harv}} ==Career== He was the professor of political science and served as a director of the [[Centre for Studies in Social Sciences, Calcutta]] and is currently a professor (honorary) of the CSSSC and professor of [[anthropology]] and [[MESAAS|South Asian studies]] at [[Columbia University]] in [[New York City|New York]].{{cite web|title=Centre for Social Sciences, Calcutta|url=http://www.cssscal.org/partha_chatterjee_contact.html|website=www.cssscal.org|accessdate=5 June 2017}} He was a founder-member of the [[Subaltern Studies Collective]]. He is a [[joint]]-[[editor in chief|editor]] of ''Baromash'', a biannual Bengali literary journal published from Calcutta. In addition to numerous books in English, he has published collections of essays in Bengali.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} ==Publications== ;Books: *1986. {{for|the American physician|Robert Michels (physician)}} [[File:Robert-michels.jpg|thumb|right|Robert Michels]] '''Robert Michels''' ({{IPA-de|ˈmɪçəls|lang}}; 9 January 1876, [[Cologne]], [[Imperial Germany|Germany]] – 3 May 1936, [[Rome]], [[Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)|Italy]]) was a [[Germany|German]]-born [[Italy|Italian]] [[sociologist]] who contributed to [[elite theory]] by describing the political behavior of intellectual elites. He belonged to the [[Italian school of elitism]].<ref>Robert A. Nye, ''The Anti-Democratic Sources of Elite Theory: Pareto, Mosca, Michels'', Sage, 1977, p. 30.</ref><ref>J. J. Chambliss (ed.), ''Philosophy of Education: An Encyclopedia'', Routledge, 2013, p. 179.</ref> He is best known for his book ''[[Political Parties (book)|Political Parties]]'', published in 1911, which contains a description of the "[[iron law of oligarchy]]." He was a friend and disciple of [[Max Weber]], [[Werner Sombart]] and [[Achille Loria]]. Politically, he moved from the [[Social Democratic Party of Germany]] to the [[Italian Socialist Party]], adhering to the Italian [[revolutionary syndicalist]] wing and later to [[Italian Fascism]], which he saw as a more democratic form of [[socialism]]. His ideas provided the basis of [[moderation theory]] which delineates the processes through which radical political groups are incorporated into the existing political system.
==Biography== Michels born to a wealthy [[Germans|German]] family, studied in [[England]], [[Paris]] (at the [[University of Paris|Sorbonne]]), and at universities in [[Munich]], [[Leipzig]] (1897), [[Halle, Saxony-Anhalt|Halle]] (1898), and [[Turin]]. He became a [[Socialist]] while teaching at the [[University of Marburg]] and became active in the [[Social Democratic Party of Germany]] for whom he was an unsuccessful candidate in the [[German federal election, 1903]]. In Italy, he associated with [[:it:sindacalismo rivoluzionario#Il sindacalismo rivoluzionario in Italia|Italian revolutionary syndicalism]], a leftist branch of the [[Italian Socialist Party]] (PSI). He left both parties in 1907.<ref name="PC71">{{cite journal|last=Cook|first=Philip|date=August 1971|title=Robert Michels's Political Parties in Perspective|journal=Journal of Politics|publisher=University of Chicago Press {{Subscription required}}|volume=33|issue=3|pages=777–778|jstor=2128281}}</ref>
He achieved international recognition for his historical and sociological study, ''Zur Soziologie des Parteiwesens in der modernen Demokratie. Untersuchungen über die oligarchischen Tendenzen des Gruppenlebens'', which was published in 1911; its title in English is ''[[Political Parties (book)|Political Parties: A Sociological Study of the Oligarchical Tendencies of Modern Democracy]]''. In it, he presented his "[[Iron law of oligarchy]]" theory that political parties, including those considered socialist, cannot be democratic because they quickly transform themselves into bureaucratic oligarchies.
Michels was considered a brilliant pupil of [[Max Weber]], who began publishing his writings in the ''[[Archiv für Sozialwissenschaft und Sozialpolitik]]'' in 1906<ref>{{cite journal|last=Scaff|first=Lawrence|date=May 1981|title=Max Weber and Robert Michels|journal=American Journal of Sociology|publisher=University of Chicago Press {{Subscription required}}|volume=86|issue=6|page=1269|jstor=2778815|doi=10.1086/227385}}</ref> and appointed him as co-editor in 1913, but they disagreed over Michels' opposition to [[World War I]].<ref name="PC71"/>
Michels criticized what he perceived to be [[Karl Marx]]'s [[materialistic]] [[determinism]]. Michels borrowed from [[Werner Sombart]]'s historical methods. Because Michels admired Italian culture and was prominent in the [[social sciences]], he was brought to the attention of [[Luigi Einaudi]] and [[Achille Loria]]. They succeeded in procuring for Michels a professorship at the [[University of Turin]], where he taught [[economics]], [[political science]] and [[socioeconomics]] until 1914. He then became professor of economics at the [[University of Basel]], Switzerland, a post he held until 1928.<ref name="CA04">{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G2-3412600198.html|title=Michels, Robert 1876-1936|date=January 2004|work=Contemporary Authors {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=26 December 2014}}</ref>
In 1924 he joined the [[Fascist Party]], led by [[Benito Mussolini]], former director of the Italian Socialist Party's newspaper "[[Avanti! (Italian newspaper)|''Avanti!'']]". Michels was convinced that the direct link between [[Benito Mussolini]]'s [[charisma]] and the working class was in some way the best means to realize a real lower social class government without political bureaucratic mediation. In 1928, he became professor of economics and the history of doctrines at the [[University of Perugia]]<ref name="CA04"/> and occasionally lectured in [[Rome]] where he died on May 3, 1936.

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} {{Use British English|date=August 2017}} [[File:robin-ramsay-lobster.jpg|thumb|right|Robin Ramsay in 2007]] '''Robin Ramsay''' (born 1948, [[Edinburgh]], Scotland) is a Scottish [[author]], and co-founder and [[editing|editor]] of the magazine, ''[[Lobster (magazine)|Lobster]]''. Ramsay writes about politics and conspiracy theories. His books have been published by [[HarperCollins]] and [[The Pocket Essentials|Pocket Essentials]]. His writings have resulted in him receiving death threats from the fascist group [[Combat 18]].<ref>Francis Elliott, "New Labour unshelled", ''Hull Daily Mail'', 1 June 1998, page 14</ref>
Ramsay studied at [[Stirling University]] but left after a term and moved to [[London]]. He later took a degree at [[Hull University]]. While there, he became interested in the [[John F. Kennedy assassination]].
While investigating the case Ramsay met fellow Kennedy assassination enthusiast Stephen Dorril and together they started a magazine about [[parapolitics (disambiguation)|parapolitics]]. ''[[Lobster (magazine)|Lobster]]'' first appeared in September 1983 as a 24-page [[ISO 216|A5]] magazine. He also draws on his research and writes a regular monthly column in the ''[[Fortean Times]]''.
==Conspiracy theories== Although Ramsay's magazine Lobster includes articles on conspiracy theories, and he has written a book on the subject, [[Gareth Mclean]] writing ''[[The Scotsman]]'' newspaper, says that Ramsay "hates conspiracy theories", quoting him as saying "The term 'conspiracy theory' is used by various intellectual establishments to dismiss people like me. It's irritating but there's nothing you can do about it."<ref>Gareth Mclean, "They're Out to Get You", ''The Scotsman'', 9 October 1999, Saturday, page 6</ref>
==Personal== Ramsay is the eldest child of a food chemist father and housewife mother.<ref>"Shock Lobster", ''Sunday Herald'', 17 August 2003. [http://archives.econ.utah.edu/archives/a-list/2003w33/msg00042.html Online at U. Utah] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130227034314/http://archives.econ.utah.edu/archives/a-list/2003w33/msg00042.html |date=27 February 2013 }}</ref>
''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' journalist [[Robert McCrum]] describes Ramsay as "an extrovert, fast-talking Scot with jack-of-all-trades experience in alternative journalism, jazz music and the theatre".<ref>Robert McCrum, "Inside Story: In the lair of the lobster - Stephen Dorril and Robin Ramsey edit a left-wing journal that offers succour to conspiracy theorists and keeps the professionals on their toes", ''The Guardian'' (London), 31 August 1991</ref>
In July 1988, Ramsay made [[After_Dark_(TV_series)#.22British_Intelligence.22|an extended appearance]] on the [[Channel 4]] discussion programme ''[[After_Dark_(TV_series)|After Dark]]'', alongside [[Merlyn Rees]], [[H. Montgomery Hyde]] and others.
== Published books == *''Smear: Wilson and the Secret State'' (1992) [[HarperCollins]], {{ISBN|0-586-21713-4}} (co-authored with Stephen Dorril) *''Prawn Cocktail Party: The Hidden Power of New Labour'' (1998) Vision Paperbacks, {{ISBN|1-901250-20-2}} *''New Labour'' (2002) [[The Pocket Essentials|Pocket Essentials]], {{ISBN|1-903047-83-8}} *''Conspiracy Theories'' (2006) Pocket Essentials, {{ISBN|1-904048-65-X}} *''Politics and Paranoia'' (2008) Picnic Publishing {{ISBN|0-9556105-4-0}} *''Who Shot JFK?'' (2nd ed. 2009) Pocket Essentials, {{ISBN|1-84243-232-X}}

One man's search to uncover what lies beneath", ''Hull Daily Mail'', 13 July 2007 Friday, page 10 *"Shock Lobster", ''Sunday Herald'', 17 August 2003. [https://web.archive.org/web/20130227034314/http://archives.econ.utah.edu/archives/a-list/2003w33/msg00042.html Online at U. Utah]

'''Rozena Maart''' (born 1962<ref>{{cite LAF|id=nr98-1847}}</ref>) is a South African writer, and professor, currently living in Durban. She is the Director for the Centre for Critical Research on Race and Identity. She has been recognized for her writing, and for her work opposing [[apartheid]] and violence against women. She has lectured throughout Canada, the United States and many parts of the world.
She was born in [[District Six, Cape Town]], South Africa, the old slave quarter of Cape Town. Her family was forcibly removed from District Six in 1973 as a result of the government’s Forced Removal Act. In 1987 when she was 24, Maart was nominated for the “Woman of the Year” award hosted in [[Johannesburg]], for her work opposing violence against women and for starting, with four women, the first Black feminist organization in Cape Town, Women Against Repression (WAR).
She moved to Canada in 1989 and published her first book of poetry in 1990, ''Talk About It!''. She won the [[Journey Prize]] in 1992 for her short story "No Rosa, No District Six", which later appeared in her debut short story collection "Rosa's District Six." She is the author of several books of poetry, short fiction, non-fiction and novels, most recently the novel ''The Writing Circle'', published in 2007 ([[TSAR Publications]]), which is being made into a feature film. ''Rosa's District Six'' made the weekly bestseller list in Canada in 2006 and the HOMEBRU 2006 list in South Africa.
She has a PhD from the [[University of Birmingham]], U.K. (1993–1996) Centre for Cultural Studies.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://rozenamaart.wordpress.com/resume/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-12-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141223135734/http://rozenamaart.wordpress.com/resume/ |archivedate=2014-12-23 |df= }}</ref>
Her work examines relationships between and among Political Philosophy, Black Consciousness, Derrida and Deconstruction, Psychoanalysis, Feminist Theory, and Critical Theories of race and racism.
Maart recently served on the UNESCO Scientific Committee for the South-South Philosophical Dialogues, which produced a Philosophical textbook covering four regions—Africa, Asia, South and Central America and the Arab region—in four languages (English, French, Spanish and Arabic)
In 2010 The Writing Circle was noted as one of the ten top books in South African literature in her homeland, South Africa and nominated by the African Studies Association for the Aidoo-Snyder Book Prize

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Sarah Silverman | image = Sarah Silverman DNC July 2016.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Silverman at the [[2016 Democratic National Convention]] | birth_name = Sarah Kate Silverman | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1970|12|1}} | birth_place = [[Bedford, New Hampshire]], U.S.<!--As per WP:LINKDIRECT and Template:infobox person, birth/death place indicates city, state, then country. No need to spell out "United States; 'U.S.' is fine.--> | medium = Stand up, television, film, radio | genre = [[Ribaldry#Blue comedy|Blue comedy]], [[black comedy]], [[political satire]], [[insult comedy]], [[Comedy music|musical comedy]], [[character comedy]] | active = 1990–present | influences = [[Steve Martin]], [[Larry David]], [[Joan Rivers]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Joan Rivers: In pictures |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-28975074 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=September 4, 2014 |accessdate=October 9, 2014}}</ref> [[Moms Mabley]] | domesticpartner = {{Plainlist| * [[Jimmy Kimmel]] (2002–2009) * [[Michael Sheen]] (2014–2017) }} | relatives = {{Plainlist| * [[Laura Silverman]] (sister) * [[Susan Silverman]] (sister) }} }} '''Sarah Kate Silverman''' (born December 1, 1970)<ref name=UK_bio_channel>{{cite web|url=http://www.thebiographychannel.co.uk/biographies/sarah-silverman.html|title=Sarah Silverman profile at|publisher=The Biography Channel|accessdate=February 14, 2014}}</ref> is an American stand-up comedian, actress, producer, and writer. Her comedy addresses social [[taboo]]s and controversial topics, such as [[racism]], [[sexism]], [[politics]], and [[religion]], sometimes having her comic character endorse them in a [[Satire|satirical]] or [[deadpan]] fashion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/culturebox/2005/11/irony_maiden.html|title=Irony Maiden|last=Anderson|first=Sam|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|date=November 10, 2005|accessdate=November 3, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/nyclife/0704,musto,75611,15.html|title=Sarah Silverman Is My Kind of Cunt (hell yeah)|last=Musto|first=Michael|authorlink=Michael Musto|date=January 16, 2007|work=The Village Voice|pages=16–20|accessdate=February 25, 2008}}</ref><ref name="slate_anderson">{{cite web|last=Anderson|first=Sam|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2130006|title=Irony Maiden|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|date=November 10, 2005|accessdate=February 25, 2008}}</ref> For her work on television, she has won two [[Primetime Emmy Award]]s.
Silverman was a writer and occasional performer on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', and starred in and produced ''[[The Sarah Silverman Program]]'', which ran from 2007 to 2010 on [[Comedy Central]], for which she was nominated for a [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series]].<ref name="mediaweek">{{cite news|url=http://www.mediaweek.com/mw/news/cabletv/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003541857|title=Comedy Central's Silverman Spells Ratings Gold|first=Anthony|last=Crupi|date=February 5, 2007|work=Mediaweek|accessdate=February 25, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071103013411/http://www.mediaweek.com/mw/news/cabletv/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003541857|archivedate=November 3, 2007}}</ref> She released an autobiography ''[[The Bedwetter]]'' in 2010. She also appeared in other television programs, such as ''[[Mr. Show with Bob and David|Mr. Show]]'' and ''[[V.I.P. (TV series)|VIP]]'', and starred in films, including ''[[Who's the Caboose?]]'' (1997), ''[[School of Rock]]'' (2003), ''[[Wreck-It Ralph]]'' (2012), and ''[[A Million Ways to Die in the West]]'' (2014). In 2015, she starred in the drama ''[[I Smile Back]]'', for which she was nominated for a [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Leading Role]].
During the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 election]], she became increasingly politically active; she initially campaigned for [[Bernie Sanders]], but later spoke in support of [[Hillary Clinton]] at the [[2016 Democratic National Convention]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Since 2017, she has hosted the [[Hulu]] [[web television]] [[late-night talk show]], ''[[I Love You, America with Sarah Silverman]]''.
==Early life== Silverman was born in [[Bedford, New Hampshire]],<ref name="newhampshire1">{{cite web|url=http://www.newhampshire.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/99999999/NEWHAMPSHIRE09/110429424|title=Sarah Silverman profile at|publisher=Newhampshire.com|accessdate=April 18, 2014}}</ref><ref name="biography1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.biography.com/people/sarah-silverman-320538#awesm=~oBtCPGSfIxu1UY|title=Sarah Silverman profile at|work=''biography.com''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tmz.com/person/sarah-silverman|title=Sarah Silverman News, Pictures, and Videos|publisher=TMZ.com|date=February 6, 2014|accessdate=April 18, 2014}}</ref> to Beth Ann (née Halpin; 1941–2015)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/unionleader/obituary.aspx?pid=175547798|title=Beth Ann O'Hara Obituary|publisher=New Hampshire Union Leader|date=August 21, 2015|accessdate=30 March 2016}}</ref> and Donald Silverman. She was raised in [[Manchester, New Hampshire]]. Beth had been [[George McGovern]]'s personal campaign photographer and would found the theater company New Thalian Players, while Donald has training as a social worker and also ran the clothing store Crazy Sophie's Outlet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tmz.com/person/sarah-silverman|title=Sarah Silverman News, Pictures, and Videos|website=''TMZ.com''|publisher=TMZ|accessdate=January 4, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Newman|first=Judith|date=May 7, 2010|title=From Sarah Silverman, an Adorable Look, Followed by a Sucker Punch|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/09/fashion/09sarah.html|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=January 4, 2014}}</ref> Silverman's parents divorced and later remarried others.<ref name="JJsister">{{cite news|url=http://jewishjournal.com/culture/arts/15715/|title=My sister Sarah|last=Silverman|first=Susan|date=November 15, 2007|work=[[The Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles|Jewish Journal]]|accessdate=October 9, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://donaldsilverman.com/DonaldSilverman/Donald_Silverman_Web.html|title=Donald Silverman News Enjoy|publisher=Donald Silverman|accessdate=October 17, 2012|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BTztWObL?url=http://donaldsilverman.com/DonaldSilverman/Donald_Silverman_Web.html|archivedate=October 17, 2012|df=mdy-all}} , [https://www.webcitation.org/6BTzyyCAy?url=http://donaldsilverman.com/DonaldSilverman/Meet_the_Family.html "Meet the Family"], and [https://www.webcitation.org/6BU04fwDa?url=http://donaldsilverman.com/DonaldSilverman/Sarah.html "Family Happenings Sarah"] archived from the original.<!--The navigation pane doesn't archive in WebCitation for some reason, so each page has to be archived separately--></ref> Silverman is the youngest of five siblings. Her sisters are [[Reform Judaism|Reform]] [[rabbi]] [[Susan Silverman]], screenwriter Jodyne Silverman, and actress [[Laura Silverman]]; her brother Jeffrey Michael died when he was three months old.<ref>{{cite web|last=Silverman|first=Sarah|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=126165357|title=Sarah Silverman: Turning Ignorance Into Comedy|publisher=NPR|accessdate=April 18, 2014}}</ref> Born into a [[Jewish]] family,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/the-demented-sarah-silverman/|title=The Demented Sarah Silverman|last=|first=|date=October 19, 2008|work=CBS Sunday Morning|access-date=May 20, 2018|language=|quote=The youngest of four girls growing up in a middle-class Jewish family in New Hampshire, her parents divorced when she was 6.}}</ref> she considers herself secular and non-religious.<ref>{{cite web|first=Pamela|last=Paul|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/interrogation/2005/11/sarah_silverman.html|title=Sarah Silverman|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|date=November 10, 2005|accessdate=April 29, 2018}}</ref><ref name="CNN1">{{cite news|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1004/20/lkl.01.html|publisher=CNN|title=Interview With Michelle Obama's Brother; Interview With Sarah Silverman|date=April 20, 2010|accessdate=August 25, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Yamato |first=Jen |url=http://www.movieline.com/2011/03/sarah-silverman-talks-peep-world-and-distancing-herself-from-jewish-comedienne-sarah-silverman.php |title=Sarah Silverman Talks Peep World and Distancing Herself from 'Jewish Comedian Sarah Silverman' |publisher=Movieline |date=March 25, 2011 |accessdate=May 29, 2012}}</ref> She was in attendance when women lit menorahs at the [[Western Wall]] for the first time, in December 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/12/18/sarah-silverman-western-wall-hanukkah_n_6351040.html|title=Comedian Sarah Silverman Supports Women of the Wall at Hanukkah Menorah Lighting|work=HuffPost}}</ref> Her ancestors were from Poland and Russia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z6W4k0qcGxgC|title=The Bedwetter: Stories of Courage, Redemption, and Pee|first=Sarah|last=Silverman|date=September 2, 2010|publisher=Faber & Faber|accessdate=July 26, 2016|via=Google Books}}</ref>
The first time Silverman performed stand-up comedy was in Boston at age 17. She described her performance as "awful".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marksfriggin.com/news01/6-11-01.htm#fri|title=MarksFriggin.com – Stern Show News – Archive|accessdate=July 26, 2016}}</ref> After graduating from [[The Derryfield School]] in Manchester (Class of 1989), she attended [[New York University]] for a year but did not graduate. Instead, she performed stand-up comedy in [[Greenwich Village]].<ref name="JJsister"/><ref name="newyorker">{{cite news|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2005/10/24/051024fa_fact|title=Quiet Depravity: The demure outrages of a standup comic|first=Dana|last=Goodyear|work=[[The New Yorker]]|date=October 24, 2005|accessdate=February 25, 2008}}</ref><ref name="rollingstone">{{cite news| first=Vanessa|last=Grigoriadis| authorlink=Vanessa Grigoriadis|title=Dirty Rotten Princess|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/8719206/dirty_rotten_princess|work=Rolling Stone|date=November 3, 2005|accessdate=February 25, 2008}}</ref><ref name="nytmagazine">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/21/magazine/21WWLN_Q4.t.html|title=Funny Girl|first=Deborah|last=Solomon|work=The New York Times Magazine|date=January 21, 2007|accessdate=February 25, 2008}}</ref>
==Career==
===1992–2007: Career beginnings and ''Jesus Is Magic''=== After beginning her stand-up comedy in 1992, Silverman was part of the [[Saturday Night Live (season 19)|1993–94 season]] of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' (''SNL'') for 18 weeks as a writer and featured player. She was fired after one season where only one of the sketches she wrote survived to [[Rehearsal|dress rehearsal]] and none aired, although she did appear on the show as a cast member in skits, usually in smaller supporting roles. [[Bob Odenkirk]], a former ''SNL'' writer, explained, "I could see how it wouldn't work at ''SNL'' because she's got her own voice, she's very much Sarah Silverman all the time. She can play a character but she doesn't disappear into the character—she makes the character her."<ref name="newyorker"/> She has stated that she was not ready for SNL when she got the job.<ref name="freshair"/> She said that when she was fired it hurt her confidence for a year, but after that nothing could hurt her and that she attributes her time to SNL as being a key reason why she has been so tough in her career.<ref name="freshair"/> Later, she was grateful that her ''SNL'' time was short because it didn't end up defining her.<ref>{{cite book|last=Silverman|first=Sarah|title=The Bedwetter: Stories of Courage, Redemption, and Pee|year=2010|publisher=HarperCollins|location=New York|page=177}}</ref> She parodied the situation when she appeared on ''[[The Larry Sanders Show]]'' episode "The New Writer" (1996), playing Sanders' new staff writer, whose jokes are not used because of the chauvinism and bias of the male chief comedy writer, who favors the jokes of his male co-writers. She appeared in three episodes of ''Larry Sanders'' during its final two seasons.
She also starred in the [[HBO]] [[sketch comedy]] series ''[[Mr. Show with Bob and David|Mr. Show]]'' (1995–1997) and had the leading role for the 1997 [[independent film]] ''[[Who's the Caboose?]]'', about a pair of New York comedians (Silverman and director [[Sam Seder]]) going to Los Angeles during pilot season to try to get a part in a television series; the film features numerous young comedians in supporting roles but never received a widespread theatrical release. Silverman and Seder later made a six-episode television series sequel entitled ''[[Pilot Season (TV series)|Pilot Season]]'' in which Silverman stars as the same character and Seder again directed. She made her network standup comedy debut on the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' on July 3, 1997.<ref>{{cite web|title=Late Show with David Letterman (a Guest Stars & Air Dates Guide)|url=http://epguides.com/LateShowwithDavidLetterman/|website=''epguides.com''|accessdate=August 16, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vxHL49CcBXQ|title=YouTube|accessdate=July 26, 2017}}</ref>
Silverman made several TV program guest appearances, including on ''[[Star Trek: Voyager]]'' in the two-part time travel episode "[[Future's End]]" (1996); ''[[Seinfeld]]'' in the episode "[[The Money]]" (1997); ''[[V.I.P. (TV series)|VIP]]'' in the episode "48{{frac|1|2}} Hours" (2002); ''[[Greg the Bunny]]'' as a series regular (2002); and on the puppet television comedy ''[[Crank Yankers]]'' as the voice of Hadassah Guberman (2003, 2007). She had small parts in the films ''[[There's Something About Mary]]'', ''[[Say It Isn't So (film)|Say It Isn't So]]'', ''[[School of Rock]]'', ''[[The Way of the Gun]]'', ''[[Overnight Delivery]]'', ''[[Screwed (2000 film)|Screwed]]'', ''[[Heartbreakers (2001 film)|Heartbreakers]]'', ''[[Evolution (2001 film)|Evolution]]'', ''[[School for Scoundrels (2006 film)|School for Scoundrels]],'' and ''[[Rent (film)|Rent]],'' playing a mixture of comic and serious roles.
In 2005, Silverman released a [[concert film]], ''[[Sarah Silverman: Jesus Is Magic]]'', based on her one-woman show of the same name. [[Liam Lynch (musician)|Liam Lynch]] directed the film, which was distributed by [[Roadside Attractions]]. It received 64% positive ratings based on 84 reviews on the [[Film criticism|film critics]] aggregator Web site [[Rotten Tomatoes]],<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/sarah_silverman_jesus_is_magic/ | title=Sarah Silverman: Jesus is Magic (2005) | work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] | accessdate=February 25, 2008 }}</ref> and earned approximately $1.3 million at the box office.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=jesusismagic.htm | title=Sarah Silverman: Jesus is Magic | work=Box Office Mojo | accessdate=February 25, 2008 }}</ref> As part of the film's publicity campaign, she appeared online in ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' as the cover subject of ''[[Heeb]]'' magazine and in [[Roast (comedy)|roasts]] on Comedy Central of [[Pamela Anderson]] and [[Hugh Hefner]].
Silverman played a therapist in a skit for a bonus DVD of the album ''[[Lullabies to Paralyze]]'' by the band [[Queens of the Stone Age]]. Silverman also appears at the end of the video for American glam metal band [[Steel Panther]]'s "Death To All But Metal." On ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'', Silverman parodied sketches from ''[[Chappelle's Show]]'', replaying [[Dave Chappelle]]'s characterizations of [[Rick James]] and "Tyrone" as well as a [[Donnell Rawlings]] character based on the miniseries ''[[Roots (1977 miniseries)|Roots]]''. In 2006, Silverman placed 50th on ''[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]'' Hot 100 List.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maximonline.com/slideshows/index.aspx?imgCollectId=94&slideId=1955 |title=Maxim 2006 Hot 100 |work=[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]] |accessdate=February 25, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080102084323/http://www.maximonline.com/slideshows/index.aspx?imgCollectId=94&slideId=1955 |archivedate=January 2, 2008 }}</ref> In 2007, she placed 29th and appeared on the cover.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.maximonline.com/slideshows/index.aspx?slideId=3575&imgCollectId=190 | title= Maxim 2007 Hot 100 | work=[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]] | accessdate=February 25, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070517045104/http://www.maximonline.com/slideshows/index.aspx?slideId=3575&imgCollectId=190|archivedate=May 17, 2007}}</ref>
===2007–2010: ''The Sarah Silverman Program''=== [[File:Sarah Silverman.jpg|thumb|Silverman at the [[Tribeca Film Festival]] in 2007]] Her television sitcom ''[[The Sarah Silverman Program]]'' debuted on Comedy Central in February 2007, the series had 1.81 million viewers<ref name="mediaweek" /><ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/CA6414787.html?title=Article&spacedesc=news| title= ''Silverman'' Scores on Comedy | first=Rebecca | last=Stropoli | work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]] | date=February 8, 2007 | accessdate=February 25, 2008}}</ref> and portrays the day-to-day adventures of fictionalized versions of Silverman, her sister [[Laura Silverman|Laura]], and their friends. A number of comedic actors from ''Mr. Show'' have appeared on ''The Sarah Silverman Program''. Silverman was nominated for a [[61st Primetime Emmy Awards|Primetime Emmy Award]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/celebrities/sarah-silverman|title=Sarah Silverman – Television Academy|accessdate=July 26, 2016}}</ref> for her acting on the show. At the awards ceremony, she wore a fake mustache. Comedy Central canceled ''The Sarah Silverman Program'' after three seasons.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Sarah Silverman Program: TV Show Cancelled; No Season Four |url=http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/sarah-silverman-program-canceled-14887/ |publisher=TV Series Finale |date=May 12, 2010 |accessdate=October 31, 2011}}</ref>
In June 2007, she hosted the [[MTV Movie Awards]]. During her opening act, she commented on the upcoming jail sentence of [[Paris Hilton]], who was in the audience, saying: "In a couple of days, Paris Hilton is going to jail. As a matter of fact, I heard that to make her feel more comfortable in prison, the guards are going to paint the bars to look like [[human penis|penises]]. I think it is wrong, too. I just worry she is going to break her teeth on those things."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.mtv.com/ontv/movieawards/ma07/videos.jhtml| title=2007 MTV Movie Awards | publisher=MTV | format=Video | accessdate=February 25, 2008}}</ref> In September 2007, she appeared at the ''[[MTV Video Music Award]]s''. Following the [[2007 MTV Video Music Awards#Britney Spears performance|comeback performance]] of [[Britney Spears]], Silverman mocked her on stage, saying: "Wow, she is amazing. I mean, she is 25 years old, and she has already accomplished everything she's going to accomplish in her life."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.mtv.com/ontv/vma/2007/videos.jhtml |title=2007 VMA |publisher=MTV |format=Video |accessdate=February 25, 2008}}</ref>
In January 2008, she appeared on ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'' to show [[Jimmy Kimmel]], her boyfriend at the time, a special video. The video turned out to be a song called "[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!#"I'm Fucking Matt Damon" video|I'm Fucking Matt Damon]]" in which she and [[Matt Damon]] sang a duet about having an affair behind Kimmel's back. The video created an "instant YouTube sensation."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20175789,00.html|title=Behind Matt Damon's Raunchy Payback to Jimmy Kimmel|first=Julie|last=Jordan|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=February 2, 2008|accessdate=February 25, 2008}}</ref> She won an [[Emmy Award]] for Outstanding Music and Lyrics at the 60th Primetime Emmy Awards. Kimmel [[Answer song|responded]] with his own video a month later with Damon's friend [[Ben Affleck]], which enlisted a panoply of stars to record Kimmel's song "I'm Fucking Ben Affleck".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20180150,00.html|title=So Long, Sarah! Jimmy Kimmel Is, Well, 'Dating' Ben Affleck|first=Stephen M.|last=Silverman|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=February 25, 2008|accessdate=February 25, 2008}}</ref> On September 13, 2008, Silverman won a Creative Arts Emmy Award for writing the song "I'm Fucking Matt Damon".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20225675,00.html|title=Sarah Silverman Thanks Jimmy Kimmel at Creative Arts Emmys|first=Brian|last=Orloff|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=September 13, 2008|accessdate=September 14, 2008}}</ref> Silverman guest-starred in a second-season episode of the [[USA Network|USA]] cable program ''[[Monk (TV series)|Monk]]'' as Marci Maven. She returned in the sixth-season premiere and for the [[Monk (season 7)#ep7|100th episode of ''Monk'']]. According to the audio commentary on the ''[[Clerks II]]'' DVD, director [[Kevin Smith]] offered her the role that eventually went to [[Rosario Dawson]], but she turned it down out of fear of being typecast in "girlfriend roles". However, she told Smith the script was "really funny" and mentioned that if the role of [[List of View Askewniverse characters#Randal Graves|Randal Graves]] was being offered to her she "would do it in a heartbeat." She appeared in ''Strange Powers'', the 2009 documentary by Kerthy Fix and [[Gail O'Hara]] about cult songwriter Stephin Merritt and his band [[The Magnetic Fields]]. Silverman wrote a comic memoir, ''[[The Bedwetter|The Bedwetter: Stories of Courage, Redemption, and Pee]]'', which was published in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/04/books/04book.html|title=Starting Early, Swearing Often: A Smart Aleck's Story|first=Dave|last=Itzkoff|work=The New York Times|date=May 3, 2010|accessdate=30 March 2016}}</ref>
===2011–present: ''Take This Waltz'' and other projects=== [[File:Sarah Silverman performing at UCB.jpg|thumb|Silverman performing at [[Upright Citizens Brigade]] in Los Angeles, January 2013]] Silverman played Geraldine alongside [[Michelle Williams (actress)|Michelle Williams]] and [[Seth Rogen]] in ''[[Take This Waltz (film)|Take This Waltz]]'', written and directed by [[Sarah Polley]]. The film was well received when it premiered in Toronto in 2011<ref>{{cite web|title=Take This Waltz Reviews|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/take_this_waltz/reviews/?sort=fresh|publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |year=2011 |accessdate=October 31, 2011}}</ref> and was picked up by Magnolia for U.S. distribution in summer 2012.<ref>{{cite web|first=Sophia|last=Savage|title=Sarah Polley's Take This 2011|accessdate=October 31, 2011}}</ref> At the Toronto International Film Festival, she told the press she'd deliberately gained weight for the part, which required a nude scene, emphasizing that 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BPl4TTQt?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/toronto-2011-sarah-silverman-talks-233882|archivedate=October 14, 2012|deadurl=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In interviews, she warned fans not to expect too much.<ref>{{cite web|first=Mark|last=Marino|title=Sarah Silverman: Don't expect much from my nude name="ep34-sarah-silverman-mike-albo">{{cite web|url=http://howwasyourweek.libsyn.com/ep34-sarah-silverman-mike-albo|title=Ep. 34: "Satchel": Sarah Silverman, Mike Albo|accessdate=October 30, 2011}}</ref>
On September 20, 2012, Silverman made a [[public service announcement]] (PSA) criticizing new voter identification laws that create obstacles to the ability of certain groups to vote in the November presidential election, i.e., young, old, poor, and minority citizens. The project was financed by the [[Jewish Council for Education & Research]] (JCER) and was co-produced by Mik Moore<ref>{{cite web|title=Mik Moore: Co-creator of Sarah's PSAs|url=http://sarahsilvermanonline.com/2012/09/22/mik-moore-co-creator-of-sarahs-psas|accessdate=September 22, 2012|date=September 22, 2012}}</ref> and [[Ari Wallach]] (the pair that also co-produced The Great Schlep and Scissor Sheldon).<ref>{{cite web|last=Dermody|first=Katrine|title=Let My People Vote: Sarah Silverman demystifies voter ID laws (Q&A video)|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/americas/united-states/120927/let-my-people-vote-sarah-silverman-voter-id-video|work=The Global Post|accessdate=May 22, 2013}}</ref>
Silverman voiced Vanellope von Schweetz, one of the main characters in the 2012 Disney animated film, ''[[Wreck-It Ralph]]''. She is in the creative team that writes and produces the content for the YouTube comedy channel called [[Jash]]. The other partners are [[Michael Cera]], [[Reggie Watts]], and [[Tim Heidecker]] and [[Eric Wareheim]] (also known as [[Tim & Eric]]). The JASH channel premiered online March 10, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Comedy site Jash.com premieres at SXSW|url=http://blog.starcam.com/post/2013/03/11/Comedy-Site-Jash-Sarah-Silverman-Michael-Cera-Tim-and-Eric-and-Reggie-Watts.aspx|accessdate=March 28, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=JASH: Sarah Silverman, Michael Cera, Tim & Eric and Reggie Watts Create a New YouTube Channel|url=http://blogs.laweekly.com/arts/2013/03/sarah_silverman_michael_cera_t.php|accessdate=March 28, 2013}}</ref><ref name="USA Today Introduces Jash">{{cite news|last=Matheson|first=Whitney|title=JASH: Your fave comedians launch a YouTube channel|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/popcandy/2013/03/11/jash-youtube/1978521/|accessdate=March 11, 2013|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=March 11, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Rolling Stone Magazine Introduces Jash">{{cite news|last=Danton|first=Eric R.|title=Sarah Silverman, Michael Cera Launch JASH Comedy Channel on YouTube|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/videos/sarah-silverman-michael-cera-launch-jash-comedy-channel-on-youtube-20130311|accessdate=March 11, 2013|newspaper=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=March 11, 2013}}</ref> In [[Seth MacFarlane]]'s western comedy film, ''[[A Million Ways to Die in the West]]'', she played Ruth, a prostitute, who is in love with Edward ([[Giovanni Ribisi]]). It was released on May 30, 2014.
In 2013, [[HBO]] announced that Silverman would star with [[Patti LuPone]] and [[Topher Grace]] in a situation comedy pilot called ''People in New Jersey'', produced by ''SNL''{{'}}s [[Lorne Michaels]].<ref name="Sarah Silverman, Topher Grace, Patti LuPone to star in HBO's Lorne Michaels pilot">{{cite news|last=Goldberg|first=Lesley|title=Sarah Silverman, Topher Grace, Patti LuPone to star in HBO's Lorne Michaels pilot|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/sarah-silverman-topher-grace-patti-643435|accessdate=October 9, 2013|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=October 4, 2013}}</ref> The pilot was not picked up for a series order.
Since 2017, she has hosted the [[Hulu]] [[web television]] [[late-night talk show]], ''[[I Love You, America with Sarah Silverman]]''.
==Controversies==
===Media Action Network for Asian Americans incident=== [[File:Sarah Silverman (7588066284).jpg|left|thumb|Silverman at the 2013 San Diego Comic-Con International]] In a July 2001 interview on [[NBC]]'s ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'', Silverman used the ethnic slur "[[chink]]" in explaining that a friend advised her to avoid jury duty by writing a racial slur on the selection form, "something inappropriate, like 'I hate chinks.'" Silverman said she decided that she did not want to be thought of as a racist, so "I wrote 'I love chinks' – and who doesn't?"<ref name=“eonline”>{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/41903/pc-police-bust-conan-o-brien-show|title=PC Police Bust Conan O'Brien Show|first=Josh|last=Grossberg|publisher=E!|date=July 18, 2001|accessdate=30 March 2016}}</ref>
Silverman said the joke satirizes the racist thought process. [[Guy Aoki]] of the Media Action Network for Asian Americans (MANAA) objected to her use of the slur.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.manaa.org|title=Manaa: Media Action Network for Asian Americans|publisher=Manaa.orgsked|accessdate=October 30, 2008}}</ref><ref name=“eonline”/> NBC and O'Brien apologized, but Silverman did not. Later, appearing on ''[[Politically Incorrect]]'' in July and August 2001, Silverman questioned Aoki's sincerity, accusing him of exploiting the opportunity for publicity. On a later episode, Aoki appeared with Silverman and stated he did not accept Silverman's explanation, saying that it was not successful satire and that comedians should consult groups such as his before performing such material. She stated in an [[<!-- National Public Radio| -->NPR]] ''[[Fresh Air]]'' interview that she was asked to repeat the joke on ''Politically Incorrect'', among other places, but eventually dropped it from her act because she felt it was becoming stale.<ref name="freshair">{{cite news|first=Terry|last=Gross|authorlink=Terry Gross|title=Sarah Silverman: 'Jesus Is Magic'|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4994761|work=[[Fresh Air]]|date= November 9, 2005|accessdate=June 21, 2007}}</ref>
Silverman has since turned the complaint into grist for her standup act, saying that the experience helped teach her the important lesson that racism is bad: "And I mean ''bad'', like in that black way."<ref>{{cite news|first=David|last=Thorpe|url=http://www.forward.com/articles/9067|title=Is America Ready for Sarah Silverman?|work=The Jewish Daily Forward|date=January 3, 2003}}</ref>
===The Aristocrats=== A minor controversy arose over Silverman's performance in the documentary film ''[[The Aristocrats (film)|The Aristocrats]]'' (2005). The film shows her doing the [[The Aristocrats|Aristocrats joke]] – a sample of [[transgressive art]] told by numerous comedians since the [[vaudeville]] era – like it was an autobiographical account of her life as a [[Child pornography|child sex performer]]. As part of the routine, she mentioned that [[Joe Franklin]], a long-time New York radio and TV personality, would ask her to perform privately for him in his apartment, and as the punchline, [[Deadpan|deadpanned]] that "Joe Franklin raped me."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/culturebox/2005/11/irony_maiden.html | work = [[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] | title = Irony Maiden | first = Sam | last = Anderson | date = November 10, 2005| accessdate = November 12, 2018}}</ref>
After the film's release, Franklin took offense at Silverman's using his name in the routine and considered suing her. A month later, ''[[The New York Times]]'' noted he remained undecided but had said, "The best thing I could do is get Sarah better writers so she'd have funnier material."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/09/08/nyregion/08bold.html|work=The New York Times|title=Now We Feel We Really Know Her|first=Paula|last=Schwartz|date=September 8, 2005|accessdate=May 23, 2010}}</ref>
==Personal life== Silverman became a vegetarian at the age of ten.<ref name="healthyschoollunches">{{cite web | url = http://www.healthyschoollunches.org/sarah_silverman_healthy_school_meals_act_letter.cfm | title = Sarah Silverman Urges Congress to Pass Healthy School Meals Act, H.R. 4870 | publisher=Silverman letter, via HealthySchoolLunches.com|accessdate= October 28, 2012|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100702004341/http://www.healthyschoollunches.org/sarah_silverman_healthy_school_meals_act_letter.cfm | archivedate=July 2, 2010}}</ref> She is open about her lifelong battle with [[Major depressive disorder|clinical depression]], which at one point led to her developing an addiction to [[Alprazolam|Xanax]]. She credited her subsequent emotional health to taking the prescription drug [[Sertraline|Zoloft]].<ref name="rollingstone"/><ref name="slate_paul">{{cite web|last=Paul|first=Pamela|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2129955|title=Sarah Silverman|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|date=November 10, 2005|accessdate=February 25, 2008}}</ref><ref name="usmagazine">{{cite news|last=Hancock|first=Noelle|date=May 15, 2007|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/sarah_silverman|title=Sarah Silverman's Depression Confession|work=[[Us Weekly]]|page=10|id=Issue 642|accessdate=February 25, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080104212407/http://usmagazine.com/sarah_silverman|archivedate=January 4, 2008}}</ref> She struggled with [[Nocturnal enuresis|bedwetting]] from the time she was young until well into her teens and stated in a 2007 interview that she had wet the bed recently.<ref name="jkl"/>
Silverman's autobiography, published in April 2010, entitled ''[[The Bedwetter]]'', explores the subject of bed wetting, among other subjects. She stated she did not want to get married until [[Same-sex marriage in the United States|same-sex couples]] were able to.<ref name="advocate">{{cite web|url=http://www.advocate.com/Arts_and_Entertainment/People/Sarah_Silverman|title=Sarah Silverman|first=Brandon|last=Voss|authorlink=Brandon Voss|work=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]|date=March 13, 2007|accessdate=February 25, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100210104626/http://www.advocate.com/Arts_and_Entertainment/People/Sarah_Silverman/|archivedate=February 10, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In 2014, she tweeted "Just read that I wanna get married which is hilarious b/c I will never get married," adding, "Why would I want the govt involved in my love life? Ew. It's barbaric."<ref>{{cite web |first=Brittney |last=Stephens |url=https://www.popsugar.com/celebrity/Celebrities-Who-Dont-Want-Get-Married-34508082 |title=Stars That Have Said They Don't Want to Get Married |work=Popsugar |date=January 27, 2016 |accessdate=October 7, 2016 }}</ref>
She stated she does not want to have biological children because "there's just millions of kids that have no parents" in the world and to avoid the risk that they might inherit her depression.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2005/nov/02/entertainment/et-sarah2|page=2|title=Almost nothing is off-limits for Sarah Silverman|first=Robin|last=Abcarian|date=November 2, 2005|website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=February 2, 2012|deadurl=no|archivedate=April 25, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160425092547/http://articles.latimes.com/2005/nov/02/entertainment/et-sarah2/2}}</ref> In 2017, Silverman also said that she has prioritized her artistic career, constantly on tour, instead of motherhood.<ref>{{cite tweet|user=SarahKSilverman|author=Sarah Silverman|number=836413899020738560|date=February 28, 2017|title=As a comic always working & on the road I have had to decide between motherhood & living my fullest life & I chose the latter.}}</ref>
Silverman's real-life sister, [[Laura Silverman|Laura]], played her sister on ''[[The Sarah Silverman Program]].'' An older sister, [[Susan Silverman|Susan]], is a [[rabbi]] who lives in [[Jerusalem]] with her husband, [[Yosef Abramowitz]], the co-founder and president of [[Arava Power Company]], and their five children.<ref name="JJsister"/><ref name="youtube.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KgjM-y8uNDc|title=Sister Act |via=YouTube|date=November 10, 2011|accessdate=May 29, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Debra|last=Nussbaum Coen|title=The Paradox of Yossi Abramowitz|url=http://www.thejewishweek.com/features/paradox_yossi_abramowitz |work=The New York Jewish Week|date=June 30, 2006|accessdate=October 15, 2012}}</ref> Silverman considers herself culturally Jewish, which she has frequently mined for material, but says she is agnostic<ref name="CNN1"/> and does not follow Judaism, claiming, "I have no religion. But culturally I can't escape it; I'm very Jewish."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/07/arts/television/07sara.html|title=Message to Your Grandma: Vote Obama|work=The New York Times|accessdate=February 16, 2009|first=Dave|last=Itzkoff|date=October 7, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2129955|title=Sarah Silverman|work=Slate|accessdate=February 16, 2009}}</ref>
Silverman dated comedian and fellow ''SNL'' writer [[Dave Attell]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/may/04/entertainment/la-et-book-20100504|title=Book review: 'The Bedwetter' by Sarah Silverman|first=Joshua|last=Sandoval|date=May 4, 2010|publisher=|via=LA Times}}</ref> Silverman began dating [[Jimmy Kimmel]] in 2002.<ref name="jkl">{{cite web|url=http://www.esquire.com/features/what-ive-learned/ESQ0107silvermanandkimmel|title=What I've Learned: Sarah Silverman & Jimmy Kimmel|last=Sagar |first=Mike|work=[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]|date=February 20, 2007|accessdate=February 25, 2008}}</ref> She referred to the relationship in some of her comedy, joking: "I'm Jewish, but I wear this [[Saint Christopher]] medal sometimes; my boyfriend is Catholic – but you know ... it was cute the way he gave it to me. He said if it doesn't burn a hole through my skin, it will protect me."<ref name="newyorker"/> In July 2008, ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' reported that the couple had split. However, in October 2008, the media reported they were on "the road back to being together".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,434182,00.html|title=Jimmy Kimmel and Sarah Silverman Reportedly Back Together|publisher=Fox News Channel|date=October 8, 2008|accessdate=October 30, 2008}}</ref> The couple attended the wedding of [[Howard Stern]] and [[Beth Ostrosky Stern|Beth Ostrosky]],<ref>{{cite web|title=First Peek: Howard Stern's Wedding Photo|work=Us magazine.com|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/news/first-peek-howard-sterns-wedding-photo|date=October 8, 2008|accessdate=April 6, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081009104945/http://www.usmagazine.com/news/first-peek-howard-sterns-wedding-photo|archivedate=October 9, 2008}}</ref> but split again in March 2009.<ref>{{cite news|last=Tan|first=Michelle|title=Sarah Silverman and Jimmy Kimmel Call It Quits – Again|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20263895,00.html}}</ref> At the [[Emmy Awards]] in August 2014, Silverman acknowledged she and Welsh actor [[Michael Sheen]] were in a relationship.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/576300/jimmy-kimmel-asks-ex-girlfriend-sarah-silverman-about-her-current-boyfriend-michael-sheen|title=Jimmy Kimmel Asks Ex-Girlfriend Sarah Silverman About Her Current Boyfriend Michael Sheen|first=Zach|last=Johnson|publisher= [[E! News]]|date=September 5, 2014| accessdate=February 5, 2018}}</ref> Silverman said in February 2018 that the two had broken up over the holidays.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/sarah-silverman-michael-sheen-split-after-nearly-four-years-together/|title=Sarah Silverman and Michael Sheen Split After Nearly Four Years Together|work=[[Us Weekly]]| date=February 5, 2018|first=Sarah |last=Hearon|accessdate=February 5, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite tweet|user=SarahKSilverman|first=Sarah|last=Silverman|authorlink=Sarah Silverman|number=960589708400017408|date=February 5, 2018|title=The great @michaelsheen & I consciously uncoupled over Christmas.|accessdate=February 5, 2018|url=https://twitter.com/SarahKSilverman/status/960589708400017408|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180205215453/https://twitter.com/SarahKSilverman/status/960589708400017408|archivedate=February 5, 2018|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In July 2016, Silverman spent a week in the [[intensive care unit]] at [[Cedars Sinai Hospital]] with [[epiglottitis]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://apnews.com/efcc95370b474808809bb01aa3ff23e4/comedian-sarah-silverman-lucky-be-alive-after-surgery|title=Comedian Sarah Silverman 'lucky to be alive' after surgery|website=''apnews.com''|accessdate=June 2, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.etonline.com/news/192649_sarah_silverman_says_she_almost_died_last_week/|title=Sarah Silverman Says She Almost Died Last Week, Recounts Terrifying ICU Story|website=''etonline.com''|accessdate=June 2, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://people.com/tv/sarah-silverman-contracted-epiglottitis-spent-five-days-in-icu/|title=Sarah Silverman Contracted Epiglottitis: Spent Five Days in ICU|date=July 6, 2016|website=People|accessdate=June 2, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/style/2016/07/sarah-silverman-epiglottitis-nearly-died|title=Sarah Silverman Says She Nearly Died Last Week|first=Hilary|last=Weaver|website=Vanity Fair|accessdate=June 2, 2017}}</ref>
In an interview on ''[[The Howard Stern Show]]'' in October 2018, Silverman revealed that she was one of several female comedians who witnessed fellow comic [[Louis C.K.]] masturbate, which she said was a consensual act. Silverman stated she felt the act was not abusive, because of the absence of a power differential between the two.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Evans|first=Greg|url=https://deadline.com/2018/10/sarah-silverman-louis-c-k-masturbation-howard-stern-consent-1202487265/|title=Sarah Silverman Says Louis C.K. Masturbated In Front Of Her With Consent|publisher=Deadline|date=2018-10-22|accessdate=2018-10-27}}</ref>
==Politics and activism== [[File:Sarah Silverman Introduces Bernie Sanders in L.A..webm|thumb|Silverman introduces [[Bernie Sanders]] at an August 2015 [[Bernie Sanders presidential campaign, 2016|campaign]] rally in Los Angeles]] In 2015, she signed an open letter which the [[ONE Campaign]] had been collecting signatures for; the letter was addressed to [[Angela Merkel]] and [[Nkosazana Dlamini-Zuma]], urging them to focus on women, as they serve as the head of the G7 in Germany and the AU in Ethiopia, respectively, which will start to set the priorities in development funding before a main UN summit in September 2015 that will establish new development goals for the generation.<ref>{{cite web|author=Tracy McVeigh |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2015/mar/07/povert-sexist-letter-women-equality-gaga-sandberg-beyonce |title=Poverty is sexist: leading women sign up for global equality | Life and style |work=The Guardian |accessdate=8 May 2015}}</ref>
During the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 election]], she became increasingly politically active. In 2015, Silverman endorsed Vermont Senator [[Bernie Sanders]] for [[President of the United States]], saying, "He says what he means & he means what he says & he's not for sale". She had previously introduced Sanders at a rally in Los Angeles, California that drew an audience of over 27,500 people.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/meet-bernie-sanders-top-celebrity-backers/story?id=33020601|title=Meet Bernie Sanders' top celebrity backers|first1=Summer|last1=Fields|first2=Louise|last2=Simpson|publisher=ABC News|date=August 11, 2015|accessdate=30 March 2016}}</ref>
Though she initially supported Sanders, she later spoke in support of [[Hillary Clinton]] at the [[2016 Democratic National Convention]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> In her convention speech, she urged other Sanders supporters to back Clinton and, later, amid some boos from some Sanders supporters, said, "Can I just say? To the 'Bernie or Bust' people, you're being ridiculous."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/politics/trailguide/la-na-democratic-convention-2016-live-a-blunt-message-from-sarah-silverman-1469496266-htmlstory.html|title=Democratic National Convention day 1: Bernie Sanders tells supporters, 'Hillary Clinton must become the next president of the United States'|accessdate=July 26, 2016|via=Los Angeles Times}}</ref><ref name = "Sarah Silverman" >{{cite news|date=July 24, 2016|title=Democratic National Convention live updates: 'You're being ridiculous,' Sarah Silverman tells Sanders die-hards|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/politics/trailguide/la-na-democratic-convention-2016-live-a-blunt-message-from-sarah-silverman-1469496266-htmlstory.html}}</ref> ''[[The Washington Post]]'' and ''[[Politico]]'' called this one of the most memorable moments of the night.<ref name="WaPo day 1" >{{cite news|date=July 25, 2016|title=Winners and losers from the first night of the Democratic convention|work=The Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/07/25/winners-and-losers-from-the-1st-night-of-the-democratic-convention/ }}</ref><ref name="Politico 11" >{{cite news|date=July 25, 2016|title=The 11 most memorable lines of the first day|publisher=[[Politico]]|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/07/memorable-lines-dnc-226193}}</ref> ''[[The New York Times]]'' called her speech "the perfect breath of fresh air".<ref name=":1">{{cite news|date=July 24, 2016|title=Sarah Silverman Tames the Beast|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/07/25/opinion/campaign-stops/Hillary-Clinton-convention-Day-1.html}}</ref> [[Michael Grunwald]] of ''Politico'' coined the term "Silverman Democrats" for Sanders supporters who followed Silverman's advice to support Clinton in the presidential election.<ref name="grunwald">{{cite news|last1=Grunwald|first1=Michael|title=Meet the Sarah Silverman Democrats|url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/07/sarah-silverman-bernie-sanders-214105?lo=ap_c1|accessdate=July 27, 2016|publisher=Politico|date=July 26, 2016}}</ref>
